metadata.hint: Use power rule and apply limits

metadata.key_insight: Integral of constant is constant times interval length

MATH_INTDEF_E_003.subject: Mathematics

metadata.key_insight: Evaluate at upper minus lower limit

metadata.key_insight: Area under curve is definite integral

MATH_INTDEF_E_005.subject: Mathematics
MATH_INTDEF_E_005.question_text: If ∫₁³ f(x) dx = 5, find ∫₃¹ f(x) dx.

metadata.key_insight: Order of limits matters - reversal changes sign

MATH_INTDEF_E_006.subject: Mathematics
MATH_INTDEF_E_006.question_text: If ∫₀² f(x) dx = 3 and ∫₂⁵ f(x) dx = 7, find ∫₀⁵ f(x) dx.

solution_steps.formula: ∫ₐᶜ f(x) dx = ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx + ∫ᵦᶜ f(x) dx

solution_steps.calculation: ∫₀⁵ f(x) dx = ∫₀² f(x) dx + ∫₂⁵ f(x) dx = 3 + 7 = 10

MATH_INTDEF_E_007.subject: Mathematics
MATH_INTDEF_E_007.question_text: Evaluate ∫₀¹ eˣ dx. Round to 2 decimals.

distractor_analysis.A: Would be true only if ∫₋ₐᵃ for even functions; same limits give 0
distractor_analysis.C: Confused with ∫₀ᵃ 1 dx = a; when limits are equal, integral is always 0
distractor_analysis.D: Forgot that same upper and lower limits always give 0 regardless of function

metadata.hint: What happens when upper = lower limit?

MATH_INTDEF_E_009.subject: Mathematics
MATH_INTDEF_E_009.question_text: If f(x) is an odd function, then ∫₋ₐᵃ f(x) dx =

distractor_analysis.B: This applies to even functions: ∫₋ₐᵃ f(x)dx = 2∫₀ᵃ f(x)dx when f(-x)=f(x)
distractor_analysis.C: Forgot the symmetry cancellation; odd functions have equal positive and negative contributions
distractor_analysis.D: Can be determined - odd function property guarantees ∫₋ₐᵃ f(x)dx = 0

MATH_INTDEF_E_010.subject: Mathematics
MATH_INTDEF_E_010.question_text: If f(x) is an even function, then ∫₋ₐᵃ f(x) dx =

distractor_analysis.A: This is for odd functions; even functions have symmetric addition, not cancellation
distractor_analysis.C: Forgot to account for both halves; even symmetry doubles the integral from 0 to a
distractor_analysis.D: King's property ∫₀ᵃ f(x)dx=∫₀ᵃ f(a-x)dx is different from even function property

MATH_INTDEF_M_015.subject: Mathematics
MATH_INTDEF_M_015.question_text: ∫ₐᵇ k dx (where k is constant) equals:

distractor_analysis.A: Missing the interval length (b-a); constant alone doesn't give the area
distractor_analysis.C: Just multiplying by upper limit ignores the lower limit
distractor_analysis.D: This is the midpoint formula, not the integral of a constant

solution_steps.explanation: Constant times the length of interval

MATH_INTDEF_M_016.subject: Mathematics
MATH_INTDEF_M_016.question_text: Which property holds for definite integrals?

distractor_analysis.A: Missing the negative sign; reversing limits negates the integral
distractor_analysis.C: This would mean integral equals zero, which is nonsense

metadata.hint: What happens when you reverse limits?

MATH_INTDEF_M_017.subject: Mathematics
MATH_INTDEF_M_017.question_text: Area under y=f(x) from a to b where f(x)≥0:

distractor_analysis.A: Absolute value unnecessary when f(x)≥0 already
distractor_analysis.C: Negative integral would give negative area
distractor_analysis.D: Squaring changes the function; area is just ∫f(x)dx when f≥0

distractor_analysis.B: t is dummy variable; answer must be in terms of x
distractor_analysis.C: This is indefinite integral, not derivative of definite integral
distractor_analysis.D: Derivative of integral returns the function, not zero

distractor_analysis.B: Backwards; smaller function gives smaller integral
distractor_analysis.D: There is a relation: monotonicity of integrals

distractor_analysis.A: Cannot integrate x sin x directly
distractor_analysis.C: No good substitution exists for x sin x

MATH_INTDEF_MH_007.question_text: ∫₋₂² √(4-x²) dx represents area of semicircle. Find value (2 decimals).

solution_steps.calc: x³+x is odd, so integral over symmetric limits is 0

distractor_analysis.A: This is for odd functions; even functions have additive symmetry
distractor_analysis.C: Missing the factor of 2 from symmetric doubling
distractor_analysis.D: Can be determined using even function property

MATH_INTDEF_MH_011.subject: Mathematics
MATH_INTDEF_MH_011.question_text: To find area between y=f(x) and y=g(x) on [a,b], the general formula is:

distractor_analysis.A: Only works when f≥g throughout [a,b]; general formula needs absolute value
distractor_analysis.C: Addition doesn't give area between curves; gives combined area
distractor_analysis.D: Product has no geometric meaning for area between curves

solution_steps.explanation: Absolute value ensures positive area regardless of which function is larger

metadata.hint: Need absolute value for general case
metadata.key_insight: Absolute value handles cases where functions cross

distractor_analysis.D: This is even function property, not King's
This differentiates f, not the integral with respect to x

solution_steps.calc: Complex King's application gives π ln2/8 ≈ 0.272

distractor_analysis.A: Even function over symmetric limits gives 2/3, not zero
distractor_analysis.C: ∫₀^π cos x = 0 actually, so both B and C work... let me fix

distractor_analysis.B: FTC is about calculus operations, not geometric quantities
distractor_analysis.C: FTC is about differentiation/integration, not limits/continuity
